review_title: Not a bad place to be.
pros: University of Indiana is a beautiful campus in a beautiful small town.  It is a good fit for families, and has great dining opportunities, as well as decent grocery stores.  The University seems to value it's employees, for the most part.
cons: Watch out for 'lecturer' positions.  They are very unstable and tenuous, with no real chance of advancement.

pros: Laid-back management with high standards, pleasant clients, easy to request time off, solid tips. Easy to get many hours per week right off the bat.
cons: Shifts are very overstaffed at times, so there isn't much to do all the time. However, this problem is much better than shifts being understaffed.

review_title: A wonderful place to learn complex surgical populations and cases.
job_title: RN Operating Room in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
You will learn techniques and surgical cases that many hospitals do not do.
Will train new employees to both scrub and circulate.
Precepting new employees very rewarding and satisfying.
A great place to learn organizational and management skills.
cons:
Constantly changing interns, residents.
Hard to get any time off.
Pay increases very minuscule, even for high performers.
No breaks given, except for lunch, even for twelve hour people.

pros: IU Has great health, retirement and vacation package. They offer tuition reimbursement for self and family members. It is a well respected institution.
cons: I really do not have any cons. They only thing that stands out is parking. You have to pay 50-70 dollars per month to park.

pros: Vacation and sick time.  Medical benefits.  The promise of helping students be successful at college and in life.  Great colleagues.
cons: Advancement is difficult.  People who are student focused are paid less.  Significant advancement means having to leave your current job.

pros: Abundant PTO, yay! Depends who you work for otherwise. My coworkers are great and supportive and we cultivate a good environment.
cons: I'm in the College of Arts and Sciences, therefore my salary is comparatively low. You can look up everyone's salary, so you know the grass is greener. It's IU, so there's a lot of bureaucracy. Really just any of the cons of working for a giant organization.

review_title: Great flexible work environment in a great research university on a beautiful campus
job_title: Local Service Provider in Bloomington, IN
pros: Great benefits, cooperative work environment, flexible work/life balance, access to smart and interesting people.  The technology is awesome with gigabit bandwidth internally, huge servers, and access to top name software.
cons: Some would say staff pay is low, but the benefits make up for it.

pros: Everyone is a lot of fun to work with, and for the most part everyone is competent enough to do their job - a large feat considering the staff is made up of college kids who aren't always there because they want to do their job well. Manager is solid at handling business.
cons: In the winter, it's hard. The door is constantly opening, you're freezing, and you have to stay in your business uniform.

pros: Great benefits package, lots of time off, nice perks such as annual flu shots.
cons: Low salaries, professors with huge egos, terrible hierarchy, archaic practices (tenure) lack of technology, long term employees stuck in the past with no sense of creativity or customer service.

pros: Life/Work Balance, Mission greater than one's self interest, fantastic healthcare and benefits, encouraging and positive atmosphere.
cons: Limited upward mobility, high cost of living near campus, tempting to become complacent in work role, some micro-management at the executive level. Policies don't always align with stated values.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros:
Absolutely amazing experience to use one of the few fMRI machines in the United States to conduct research on developing children! 
Truly the future of neuroscience research
cons: Long hours, unpaid - but the experience helping other and working there made it every long night worth it in the long run. fMRI tech's make tons of money if you pursue obtaining the further certifications (they are easy to get).

review_title: Prestigious university with an academic culture on steroids
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Bloomington, IN
pros: Located in a nice town. A good place to raise a family. You can find good, supportive people outside work as well as at work.
cons: The general cons of any R1 university. Super high expectations for research, which creates a very stressful atmosphere for tenure track faculty and a number of organizational pathologies.

pros: IUPUI is a centrally located campus in the city and is a very exciting place to work as an intern.  It is a world-class research institution.
cons: The parking is absolutely terrible.  Traffic can be bad at rush hour, but otherwise no issues.  Management often underutilizes staff, which leads to discontent.

pros: Health benefits are very good and cheap. Tuition benefits for employee and dependents. Discounted entry to arts and sports events. 30 days of paid time off from your first year!
cons: They will not offer you a competitive salary. No bonuses in most cases. No rewards for accomplishing some big thing.

pros: Excellent team work from all associates and co-workers. Laid back environment but hypes up for the tours and seasonal events. Happy people and helpful to train. An adult environment.
cons: Uhm, I guess if you aren't an extrovert you wouldn't like it.  But extroverts don't apply, so it works great.  I didn't have any cons.

pros: Stable Environment, Gorgeous Town, They do well to make sure your job schedule doesn't get in the way of your classes. Overall very productive environment and a beautiful student athletics academic center.
cons: Very low opportunities for raises, by no means challenging or interesting work. You'll find yourself tutoring most athletes in low level classes.

job_title: Senior Research Analyst in Bloomington, IN
pros: The expense at Bloomington is low compare to other cities. Indiana University has  beautiful campus. Colleagues at my department are very nice and easy to work with.
cons: It is a quite city. Life is not entertaining. Researcher position has limited professional advancement opportunities compared to a faculty position.

review_title: excellent working environment at Kelley School of Business - Bloomington
pros: IU focuses on employee professional development and has strong diversity commitment.  They have excellent facilities for staff and find time to incorporate events for staff and faculty to collaborate.  Bloomington IN is a good place to live and work with an excellent college town setting in central Indiana.
cons: it is a large organization that can be slow at decision making at times

review_title: Working at RPS is good for students
pros: Decent pay and flexible hours that work around a student's schedule. Co-workers and management are relaxed and fun to be around.
cons: The occasional late shift can crowd out academic and personal wellness concerns, but these rare events are not characteristic of the job as a whole.

review_title: IU is a great college with some work to do
pros:
- Great Location with lots to do
- Great motivated students
- Beautiful campus and huge work space
- good management
cons:
-the weather can be a huge downer
- sometimes IU feels too big in terms of population
- very few minorities at IU make it an unfriendly place

pros: Great work environment and the people I work with make it enjoyable to come to work.  Not to mention you get access to free software :)
cons: Yes this is higher education and they are not known to be comparable to salary ranges of the private sector, unfortunately they are about 15-20% less.  However this is made up in the benefits we receive such as retirement and health care.

job_title: Administrative, Advisor, & Adjunct in Indianapolis, IN
pros: IUPUI is a great place to work. The fringe benefit is good. You have the opportunity to go back to school, change your hours, work with great people, and it's family friendly.
cons: No opportunity for growth within a department unless you transfer to another department or apply for a position that is higher classification than what you currently has.

review_title: Great colleagues and great opportunities for expanding your skill set as a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Great people who will support you and your work as much as possible
cons: In some fields, the IU reputation isn't going as far when it comes to helping get employment in academia. Will need to be very competitive in terms of publications to have a chance at a good job.

job_title: Executive Head Chef in Bloomington, IN
pros: Great place to work, great people, lots of catering events and sporting events. Lots of opportnites and Bloomington is a wonderful small city with lots  happening.
cons: Long hours, pay could be better, feed upwards of 600 pe0ple a day plus lots of side catering ...always busy..no rest for the wicked!!

pros: Teaching is not very difficult or overwhelming even while taking other classes. I work with a great team. Workload is not too hard. Great pay for college student.
cons: Sometimes grading can be very time-consuming. We are supposed to stay at about 10 hours/week but there is no way to stay that low after teaching, office hours, and grading - we are still paid for the extra hours though.

review_title: Intensive language training has been offered at the Bloomington campus of Indiana University since 1950.
pros: Knowledge of Slavic, East European, and Central Asian languages prepares  students for exciting career opportunities in areas such as government,  higher education, not-for-profit institutions, public health, law, international  development, the military, journalism, environmental issues, the arts  and business
cons: Needs stremlined between some administrative offices

review_title: Nice place to start thinking your future
pros: I will say it depends on which lab you stay in.  But in our lab, the supervisor is so free to let you try new things. During this process, you will have a deeper thought if you are still interested in real science OR money (industry). Now I switch my career and go for money.
cons: The efficiency of OIS is sometimes poor but acceptable.

pros: Employees are enthusiastic, and the environment is laid back. IU is located in a really nice town and the university seems to value work life balance.
cons: University is so large it is easy to get lost in the shuffle. Other than that I mostly had a good experience

job_title: Applications Support Specialist in Bloomington, IN
pros: Great entry level job in IT for those who may not have much experience.  Work environment is flexible.
cons: Low pay, random hours, and no upward mobility.  Unfortunately since this is a student job it really isn't possible to move up.

review_title: Great opportunity to gain some experience and earn a reasonable stipend
pros:
– small time commitment (~5 hours a week)
– fun working with students in CL, teaching experience looks good on resume
– $10.69/hour
– get to work with great people
cons: – no real opportunities to take on additional responsibilities

review_title: Working environment is pretty good. Co-workers are pretty nice. Customers have high degree, so they are polite.
pros: You can got $8.95 employee meal after every shift no matter how long is the shift. Manager is very friendly and keeps encouraging you.
cons: You have to keep working even the cafe is pretty slow. The only thing you can do is keep cleaning and cleaning. Sometimes you cleaned one table more than 10 times.

pros: Overall, IU offers a positive work environment. Co-works are highly educated. The campus is beautiful and the city is largely a "college town." Great energy and culture.
cons: Unfortunately, many salaries do not match industry standards. They seem to pay 20% less than the average for low to mid-level administrative positions; however, they do offer amazing benefits. Most administrative positions serve a specific purpose, so there is limited upward mobility.

review_title: A good, laid back place to work
pros: I've been full time with the university for 15 years as staff in the IT Division, and it's been a good place to work, with good co-workers, and very flexible working environments
cons: The IT Building is an open office floor plan, and the noise, visual distraction, and increase in sickness are very bad.

pros: Great boss. Great way to learn more and more about what you're teaching. Great way to connected with both staff and students.
cons: Some students aren't willing to learn. If you care about teaching, it can be quite difficult to deal with as often as it happens.

pros: I  love the campus and I love being in Bloomington. Though I am ready for something new, fresh, and exciting.
cons: It does suck to walk to class a mile or so when it is cold and windy, rainy, or snowy. Thankfully not too many classes are far away.

pros: Time off, Medical benefits, 401K are above average
cons: Parking costs are high/parking availability is poor, Salaries are below competitive, hiring process takes too long.

review_title: An incredible employer with flexible scheduling
pros: Working for a university allows you to interact with a variety of individuals on a daily basis and become familiar with a breadth of information, on the job. I would highly recommend university employment.
cons: The cons are few but include lower pay. However advancement is available and highly sought after. Additionally it can sometimes be overwhelming when surrounded by such lively events and students.

pros: Indiana University opens a window of opportunity for employees. Pay increases are available at the end of the first semester.
cons: Schedule is not gauranteed. I may have to work a shift at 2 in the morning, and I am always on call.

pros: Great benefits, depending on your department, you can work uninterrupted.  They let you roll your PTO over.  Benefits packages are outstanding.
cons: No oversight or accountability  for top dogs.  Problems roll down hill.  Pay is terrible, it reflects the value they place in their employees.  In other nonprofits and universities, pay is much higher.

review_title: Old boy's club with a lack of diversity at top; Poor leadership; Lack of commitment to students experience
pros: I honestly enjoyed working at IU (for 8+ years) as long as I was able to work efficiently and work on projects that kept me busy. I was lucky to have a job during the 2008 recession. Most people in the university are nice and easy going. One of the best things about working at IU is its slow-paced environment, its vacation policy, and the fact that Bloomington is a great place to live. I made the best use of it.
cons:
However, there are negatives along with positives. Managers could do a better job. There is an increasing level of incompetence and a lack of diversity at the top except for a couple of exceptions for reasons you can imagine. Employees who do the actual work are mostly underpaid and are not appreciated for their efforts. As a result it is difficult to find someone really smart to work with. This truly affects your professional growth. And soon you end up just being another employee. 

Their is a lack of commitment to truly increase the quality of learning and education for students or consumers whichever way you look at it. The tenured faculty are a hit or a miss because they are too focused on their own research agenda. It is all about getting grants and writing papers. The IU leadership do not seem to care and the Trustees must take ownership and make people accountable. 

I have seen time and time again how petty internal politics and misplaced priorities affected student learning outcomes in my department. This is mainly due to the fact that at the school or college levels you mostly have Deans who are usually not the best leaders, administrators, or managers, and are not necessarily the best people to run a business. Also, if you do NOT have a PhD, then you will not be valued for the great ideas or opinions you have if you are dealing with a leadership that includes professors or associate professors. Leadership play favorites. As a result, things suffer.

I would say this - if you are a minority, you will find it EXTREMELY hard to advance as a staff member unless you are willing to play politics and only care about your job security. Unfortunately, this is also an industry wide trend. The top level management, especially within UITS, is rife with Peter's Principle and will go out of their way to play dirty politics. 

I have personally seen incompetent people being promoted in jobs (with great increase in salaries) that I was qualified for. I was being passed over for middle and upper management positions mostly due to my ethnicity even though I am highly competent. It took me time to realize that it wasn't my qualifications or performance that took precedence but the fact that I was different - I looked different, I thought differently, I WAS indeed different. I truly felt that I was a second class employee in some cases. I was paid lower than my peers in same occupations for a few years. I was promoted without a pay increase in one circumstance. 

In other words, diversity isn't much appreciated at IU if YOU ARE a staff member. I must say that diversity to me includes diversity in thinking ability, the way you work etc. and it is not only limited to looking differently. There is certainly an unconscious bias against people like me. This is just an HONEST truth in my opinion. It is also the case that people mostly work in silos and there is a lack of collaboration within and across departments. This is probably one of the biggest cultural problems at IU that is bound to hurt long-term.

review_title: It's great for working while going to school
job_title: Carering Team Member in Bloomington, IN
pros: Very flexible scheduling, different kinds of events, can trade shifts easily if something comes up, a lot of fun to work in, learn good guest service
cons: Not much training which can be frustrating to all parties. Some shifts seem too early or too late for certain event set up

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Indianapolis, IN
pros: The work-life balance and benefits are great here. There's a flexible work schedule and an incredible 6 weeks of PTO with holidays. The health insurance and retirement packages are generous as well.
cons: Low salary relative to other companies in the same industry (such as programming), and limited ability for advancement.

review_title: IU plays basketball and Second Life. Who needs scholarship?
pros: In the state of Indiana, Bloomington has the best quality of life. That isn't saying much, I admit, but if you're stuck in the state, you might as well be here. The Music School is great, if you have the good luck to be associated with it. And the campus landscapers do a very nice job.
cons:
The College is tremendously underfunded, and there are huge financial inequities between schools and even between departments on campus. It's not a happy place, and most faculty I know who are not tied down by family are actively looking for jobs at other universities. Funding for research and conferences is a joke: my annual travel money won't even buy me a domestic plane ticket, so it's no surprise I don't present at conferences. Salaries for staff and for core faculty barely keep pace with cost of living: no matter how much you publish or how many teaching awards you win, don't expect a raise beyond the across-the-board annual increments unless you have a job offer from another U. Promotions don't necessarily bring salary increases. "Congratulations on getting tenure! You're now an associate professor! Here's your 1.5% raise, which you would have gotten anyway, just like everyone else; and by the way, our new assistant prof, just out of grad school, makes only $500 less than you do, even though you've been here five years and you have published two books. We're sure your new title will make you very happy." Of course, if you're in the Law School, Business School, Informatics, or football/basketball, the living is easy, since you make between twice and ten times as much as those poor fools in fine art, history, French, mathematics, and sociology, and you have a nicer office, too. 

Students are for the most part genial idiots. Administrators like to show off the IT infrastructure, but they don't appear to care about anything else. The town in general is anti-intellectual: off campus it's best not to admit to being a professor, though it's fine to admit to being a coach, NCAA violations or not.

pros: Lots of vacation and good benefits. Smart people to work with.
cons: I encountered extensive gender discrimination while at IU. The 'old boys club' is really a 'young boys club' with poor social skills pervading the workplace. The limited options mean that the salaries can be kept low.

pros: great access to software, decent health insurance rates, good retirement.
cons: hard to move around or up once you are in a position/department. You almost have to leave IU and you definately have to go to a different department to get a decent salary increase.  The pay is not very good here either.  they definately count your beneifits as part of your salary.

pros: good pay compared to work time for most of the time, instructors are typically nice to  you, sometime you can even learn things in the GA position
cons: some courses might cost you lots of time to grade and office hours, sometime students who donot do their homework would care the score very much, and try to argue for extra points which they donot deserve

pros: Working in the Kelley School of Business Information Technology office has been a great experience so far! I am always moving around on various jobs, discovering new ways of fixing technical issues, and improving my communication skills by answering phone calls, e-mails, and discussing issues face to face. The pay is also very reasonable.
cons: I am limited to what I can do for the IT department.

job_title: Assistant Foods Manager in Bloomington, IN
pros: Working with a diverse group of co-workers and students is fun. Foods service has its routine and strict health codes, but everyday different because of the student activities and class schedule.  They love our dining hall.  We have the best staff, friendly, kind and hardworking. The General Manager Jeff is the best to work for.
cons: Always having to work second shift.

pros:
It is a very nice town to live and enjoy the ideal academic environment.
People here are usually very friendly.
Cost living is low.
cons:
Small town not much can offer, need to travel if you want something different.
Parking can be sometime challenging.

pros: Of you're in IT excellent technology and colleagues - plenty of opportunities for advancement and professional development
cons: Can be high stress and difficult to strike a work / life balance

review_title: It's OK to be a RA here
pros:
Reasonable pay as a graduate student,
Not too busy,
Really can learn a lot not covered in class,
Professors are friendly.

review_title: Good experience, some awesome people, questionable strategies...
pros: There are awesome people to work with! Everyone is the best at what they do, so there isn't anyone who isn't qualified.
cons: Budgets are done weird and kind of ridiculous. Some of the things people do can be a little questionable. People are sometimes asked to do things out of work hours/ on the weekends, which can be good or bad.

pros: Since the cost of Bloomington is low, the low stipend they pay you is enough to live on. Also, the position comes with benefits including dental and health insurance which is a nice plus! The amount you are paid varies depending on your department.
cons: They do not pay very much compared to other private and state schools. This is especially true if you are in the humanities or social sciences.

review_title: Education top notch.  Business model and employee development...well, it's a crap shoot.
pros: Good location.  Beautiful campus.  Friendly people.  Good benefits.
cons: Lack of promotional opportunities for many support staff.  Lackluster salaries and merit awards.  Expensive parking rates.

pros: Great coworkers, get paid to recertify on site, great recreational facility
cons: Be prepared to work 5:30 AM shifts if you are new, long interview process with 3 separate sessions which seems excessive for a lifeguard position

pros: Students were awesome, got good experience since the department is so decentralized you basically run all the functions for your building, Bloomington is a nice city.
cons: Residential Programs and Services was a horrible environment to work in. They reward incompetence, and give promotions to people who have been there the longest. There were a number of husbands/wives working in the department (at different supervisory levels) which was so inappropriate. They've tried to recently make some changes, but they still can't retain employees. They pay terribly (no FLSA bump, big surprise), and act like any situation is the first time they've ever dealt with it. The department is not located in student affairs, and functions more as a business since it is an auxiliary. They can't ever get fully staffed, because the competent people leave. There isn't any focus on student development, because the Executive Director is an MBA who only cares about profit. I have never seen so many outrageous and negligent actions by professional staff members that put the lives of residents at risk. One person in the department almost got fired for refusing to cover up a Title IX issue. The environment is abusive, you'll be overworked (if you care - if not, you can go shopping and take naps half the day like the other staff) and the department does not care about its employees. Live-In staff apartments are horrific, they turn the heat/air/hot water off all the time and don't care, and filled with broken student lounge furniture. Run away - I'm not kidding. Nobody else at the university will want to hire you because RPS has such a bad reputation - and that's something known nationally as well. This place is messed up.

review_title: Great benefits but huge inequalities - pay, ethnic etc.
pros: benefits amazing and cannot be beat. work culture laid back that can also be a curse if you do not want to grow. good if you want to just do what you are told. risk taking not really part of the culture.
cons:
Meagre salary. Huge pay inequality - in salary of the hiring manager that is usually atleast 2-3 times an average employee salary. You feel poor for the work you do. 

High amazing pays for people at the top who are great in marketing themselves and not really do much work. Dizzying politics. Old boys club that mostly promotes the same thinking without any ethnic diversity for the most part. Self centered culture. 

I have also seen hiring managers exploit employees working on H1-B visa giving them much lower salary than less experienced peers in the SAME group just because they can do it.  Do you think that that poor soul will jeopardize being deported just so he/she can make sure his pay is fair as others? It is disgusting. Is it not breaking human rights in a way?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Bend, IN
pros: Many good professors; lots to learn in a variety of different subjects. The Science programs are all pretty good and the instructors generally know what they're talking about
cons: Some department heads/advisors can be difficult to work with at times or unavailable. Since there is a small number of students compared to a more traditional school, some of the more upper-level classes are not offered as much.

review_title: Very satisfied, good entry level work, worked with good and smart people
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Interesting work, worked with smart and awesome people, flexible hours, good entry level experience, made sure I was properly trained before sending me on my own, very loyal, easy to get time off
cons: work was interesting but repetitive , salary was a bit low and raises were minimal, hard to advance up the ranks

review_title: Employer is highly supportive of employee professional development and colleagues are wonderful to work with.
pros: Great colleagues, flexible work environment, supportive of professional development
cons: Pay is highly linked to position type, education, and years of experience. There is little flexibility for performance pay.

pros: Good hourly salary. Interest in balancing work hours with student schedule. Worth working to have a little extra pocket money.
cons: Not going to be able to make enough to pay off any debt as a student employee. Online time clock system full of bugs.

review_title: Associate Instructor (Graduate Teaching Assistantship) in Education
pros: Reasonable pay for non-STEM graduate teaching (3 courses over the fall and spring semesters), full health insurance premiums, in my department a great deal of flexibility and autonomy for the courses you teach.
cons: Unless you have a fellowship, you are not guaranteed funding from year to year, even if you are making satisfactory progress in your program of studies/scholarship.

review_title: Great Place To Work, Beautiful Campus
pros:
Talented Co-Workers
Diversity & Culture
Flexible Hours
cons: As in any academic institution, internal politics sometimes get in the way.  You can't please all of the people all of the time but the University stumbles at times trying to do so....

job_title: IT Support Specialist in Bloomington, IN
pros: Beautiful campus, great town, extremely smart co-workers, higher ups respect staff, free access to public transportation, exceptional benefits compared to other employers at the lower pay ranges.
cons: Pay slightly below market, career advancement opportunities not clear in smaller departments

pros: This job has good pay, great benefits, and is an opportunity to  teach independently as a grad student. This job is for graduate students of Indiana University, and came with my offer to enter the program.
cons: This has been a dream job. There aren't many cons. The normal bureaucratic stuff that comes with working in a University. It is nothing terrible though.

job_title: Crew Leader Custodial RPS in Bloomington, IN
pros: Beautiful Campus love the energy surrounding the campus must see it for yourself.
cons: Parking is a problem we have so many students and staff come early as a guest to park.

review_title: Low base salary but greater benefits
pros: Good learning environment, friendly co workers. Relaxed working environment.
cons: Lower base salary compared to other companies. Sometimes work load increases exponentially specially during the on-call week, poor office infrastructure in the telecom services building.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: Plenty of resources to do chemistry.
cons: Graduate students isolate themselves and do not talk to anyone. Students are bitter bringing others down around them and faculty laugh about it. Since I've been here 16 staff have left to get out of the chemistry department.  Not a supportive environment and there is a lot of tension.  Bad teaching labs.

pros:
Really depends on the instructor you are assisting with but this position provides a great opportunity for graduate students who would like to go on to a Ph.D. 
Really good pay
cons: Not many cons except that you are busy with school work at the same time that you have to grade a lot of student work (but this is expected).

pros: They provided really flexible hours and  had a great team and working environment that really welcomed new members.
cons: The job eventually began to get really repetitive after the first six months and I decided that I wouldn't be able to continue doing it

pros: Great organization.  Academic setting fostered diversity and exploration. If you are liked and have a good manager very good opportunities to learn new skills and work of different projects
cons: Low salary, cronyism, seems like some departments are more prone to spinning their wheels a lot. It may be because Of academic environment and no pressure to make a profit

review_title: IT is great but budget isn't friendly
pros: Great people (generally), and some great work.
cons: The budget for the IT areas tends to not be the best though with part time hour cuts, restrictions on what can be available, and often a lack of underemployment that higher ups don't seem to understand.

pros: Overall, being a grad student in the neuroscience program has been good.  The faculty are very supportive and you are treated well.  Good place to cut your teeth as a neuroscientist
cons: I wish there were more resources available to advise about non-traditional (read: non-academic) scientific careers.

review_title: Great flexible job to have as a student
pros: Given that it's a parttime university job, they're very flexible when it comes to what hours you can and can't work. It's also easy to sub out shifts in case you get overloaded.
cons: Job can be boring and unchallenging at times. Little room to advance if you want to stay here.

pros: There is a great community to work in, and there is always a sense of camaraderie between the workers.
cons: Since many of the workers are students, there is a lack of work ethic and the management seems to absolutely nothing to remedy the problem.

review_title: Indiana University Alumni Association is quite diverse!
pros:
-Diverse group of people
-Close knit group
-Good Benefits
cons:
-Management quality varies depending on your department
-Departments are held to different standards and those who know how to “play the game of the corporate ladder” reap the benefits

pros: Nice environment to work. Friendly place with decent benefits  where you can achieve work-life balance. You get to meet clever people who are fun to interact with
cons: It is an academic institution with all pros and cons - many positions are soft money and at some point the best strategy to get promotion is to move elsewhere.

pros: Very warm culture that respects and loves their athletics programs. The entire Indiana community welcomed me with open arms and I would do it all over again if I could.
cons: Big time commitment with school and being an athlete. Not always able to do what you want. But it's the price you pay for being at a high position.

pros: Because I want to join MBA school to leverage my working expereinces.
cons: There is nothing special but it is a little bit countery side, so sometime I feel to be bored in especially break.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bloomington, IN
pros: As a research assistant, I was able to work side by side with my employing professor and learn more than I would in a standard classroom environment.
cons: Some of the tasks can seem menial and like "busy work," but at the undergraduate level it is hard to find anything that is any more in-depth.

pros: Genuinely nice people. Free food all of the time. Lots of positions to break-in.
cons: You feel small because when you work part time, you're the smallest part of the machine. Not a lot of room for growth. As a PT employee, if offered a base retirement account, you must work for 3 years before you can take that balance. Very inconvenient.

pros: Relatively good pay, good opportunity to get teaching experience, relatively easy to balance workload and school work (most of the time, see below).
